smell_analysis.justification: Every UML and database diagram frame in the PDF contains multiple model elements (use cases, classes/tables, states, or actions); no page shows an empty diagram.

The use case diagram 'Treeningute funktsionaalne allsüsteem' shows all identified use cases connected via associations and/or include relations so that none appear as a standalone oval without any actor connection.

All use case names on the use case diagram describe distinct activities (e.g., 'Registreeri treening', 'Aktiveeri treening', 'Muuda treening mittaktiivseks', 'Unusta treening') and there is no pair of differently worded use cases that clearly denote the same activity for the same actor.

In the package/overview diagram on page 1, each listed element within a package (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Treeningu_kategooria') appears only once per package; there are no duplicate model elements with the same primary name inside the same package.

In the transformed database diagrams, repeated business data such as status codes or categories are stored in dedicated classifier tables and referenced by foreign keys (e.g., treeningu_seisundi_liik_kood, kliendi_seisundi_liik_kood); there is no clear case where the same business value is redundantly stored in multiple tables without a foreign key connection.

All use case names follow a consistent 'verb + object' imperative style, such as 'Registreeri treening', 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid', 'Lõpeta treening', and 'Unusta treening'; there is no mix of noun-only and verb-led naming.

In the 'Treeningu seisundidiagramm' state diagram, each state (Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Ootel, Lõpetatud, Unustatud) has at least one incoming transition from another state or the initial node; no state appears isolated or without a path from the initial state.

In the activity diagram 'Treeningu lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm', all actions (e.g., 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi treeningut', 'Vali treening', 'Lõpeta valitud treeningud') lie on paths starting from the initial node and leading toward the final node; there are no unreachable action nodes.

All relationships between classes and tables either show explicit multiplicities (e.g., '1', '0..*') on both ends in the class diagrams or are represented as standard foreign key/crow's-foot connectors in the transformed database diagrams, so there is no UML-style association line lacking multiplicity indicators at both ends.

Several diagrams exceed the threshold of 10 central elements: the use case diagram has 12 use cases; the class diagram 'Klassifikaatorite register' includes at least 13 classifier classes; the class diagram 'Treeningute register' shows 10 classes; and the database diagram 'Klassifikaatorite register (transformed)' contains more than 10 tables.

No single class or table is clearly connected by 6 or more distinct drawn relationship lines on any one diagram; even central elements such as 'Isik' and 'Treening' show at most around five visible connectors when counting distinct lines rather than multiple FK labels on the same line.

Across the diagrams, related elements appear spaced in a broadly uniform manner, with no relationship line spanning a distance that is clearly more than twice the average element separation on the same diagram.

All use case and activity action names start with an active verb (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Lõpeta', 'Registreeri', 'Otsi', 'Vali', 'Unusta'), so there is no use case or action whose name fails to begin with an active verb.

All class, table, attribute, and use case names are longer than three characters; the shortest observed names are domain terms like 'Riik' and 'kood', so no name of length three or less appears for these element types.

Every class name (e.g., 'Isik', 'Treening', 'Klassifikaator', 'Treeningu_kategooria_tüüp', 'Töötaja_rolli_omamine') starts with an uppercase letter and represents a singular entity; there are no lowercase-starting or pluralized class names, and register titles are treated as packages/diagrams rather than entity classes.

At least one column name starts with an uppercase letter: in 'Klientide register (transformed)', the Klient table defines the column 'Kliendi_number', whose initial 'K' violates the lowercase-first naming style for attributes/columns; most other columns such as 'kliendi_seisundi_liik_kood', 'isik_id', and 'on_nous_tylitamisega' start with lowercase.

All database tables in the transformed diagrams (e.g., 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Kylastaja', 'Treening', 'Ruum', 'Tootaja', 'Raskusaste') use singular names; plural phrases are only used in register/diagram titles and not for individual table entities.

No class, table, or attribute name is prefixed with a type-indicating abbreviation like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; only constraint and index names use prefixes such as 'PK_', 'FK_', 'pfK_', and 'IXFK_', which are explicitly allowed by the rule.
